keyTakeAways: Indigenous knowledge, such as observing natural signs and using pre-agreed signals (e.g., gunfire), is being relied upon by rural communities in northern Pakistan to predict and respond to glacial lake outburst floods (GLOFs), especially when official early warning systems fail.

Despite a $37 million GLOF-II project launched in 2017, many EWS systems remain non-functional due to lack of community trust, poor maintenance, and absence of real-time communication with rescue teams.

Residents in Gilgit-Baltistan and Khyber Pakhtunkhwa report that warnings have come from local people—like shepherds Wasiyat Khan and Mohammad Hussain—rather than from official systems, indicating a gap in technology and trust.

Pakistan is one of the top 10 most climate-vulnerable countries despite contributing less than 1% of global emissions, with rising temperatures (1.3°C since 1950s) exacerbating glacier melt and flood risks.
The effectiveness of Indigenous knowledge in saving lives during floods has been demonstrated, with no casualties in incidents where community-based alerts were used.

The lack of trust in government EWS systems has led to criticism from local activists and opposition leaders, with calls for investigation into system failures and misrepresentation of success stories.
The UNDP identifies systemic challenges such as weak institutional capacity, data gaps, and communication barriers as global obstacles to effective early warning systems.

namedEntities.name: Wasiyat Khan
namedEntities.whatIsThisEntity: A shepherd from Roshan Valley, Ghizer, who responded to a glacial burst by alerting villagers using mobile signals and survived the event. His actions exemplify Indigenous knowledge in disaster response.
namedEntities.whyIsThisEntityRelevantToTheArticle: Wasiyat Khan is a central example of how local Indigenous knowledge and personal initiative can save lives during GLOFs when technological systems fail, reinforcing the article’s theme of community-based resilience.

namedEntities.name: Mohammad Hussain
namedEntities.whatIsThisEntity: A shepherd from Skardu Valley, Gilgit-Baltistan, who used gunfire as a pre-agreed signal to warn villagers of a flash flood, demonstrating the use of traditional human-based early warnings.
namedEntities.whyIsThisEntityRelevantToTheArticle: Mohammad Hussain illustrates how ancestral knowledge of natural signals and response protocols is still effective and trusted in rural communities despite technological shortcomings.

namedEntities.name: Skardu Valley
namedEntities.whatIsThisEntity: A region in Gilgit-Baltistan, northern Pakistan, where flash floods and GLOFs are frequent and where Indigenous knowledge systems are widely used.
namedEntities.whyIsThisEntityRelevantToTheArticle: Skardu Valley serves as a key case study where the failure of technological early warning systems and the effectiveness of Indigenous knowledge are both observed and documented.

namedEntities.name: Ghizer
namedEntities.whatIsThisEntity: A region in northern Pakistan's Gilgit-Baltistan, home to Wasiyat Khan and other shepherds affected by glacial lake outburst floods.
namedEntities.whyIsThisEntityRelevantToTheArticle: Ghizer is highlighted as a climate-vulnerable area where Indigenous knowledge plays a crucial role in disaster response due to limited access to technology and infrastructure.

namedEntities.name: Gilgit-Baltistan
namedEntities.whatIsThisEntity: A region in northern Pakistan with over 13,000 glaciers, facing high risks from glacial lake outburst floods due to climate change.
namedEntities.whyIsThisEntityRelevantToTheArticle: Gilgit-Baltistan is a critical climate hotspot where both technological and Indigenous systems are being tested, and where community trust in EWS remains low.

namedEntities.name: Khyber Pakhtunkhwa
namedEntities.whatIsThisEntity: A province in Pakistan where glacial and flash flood risks are also present, and where Indigenous knowledge systems are used as primary warning tools.
namedEntities.whyIsThisEntityRelevantToTheArticle: Khyber Pakhtunkhwa is included in the broader climate vulnerability context and shows that the issue of trust in EWS extends beyond Gilgit-Baltistan.

namedEntities.whatIsThisEntity: The national body responsible for collecting real-time data from EWS sensors to monitor and warn of climate-related hazards.
namedEntities.whyIsThisEntityRelevantToTheArticle: It represents the official technological infrastructure that has failed to gain community trust, leading to a reliance on Indigenous methods.

namedEntities.name: National Disaster Management Authority (NDMA)
namedEntities.whatIsThisEntity: The Pakistani government agency that has assessed climate risks and issued warnings about reduced snowfall and glacier retreat.
namedEntities.whyIsThisEntityRelevantToTheArticle: NDMA provides official projections on climate risks and identifies the increasing vulnerability of northern Pakistan to GLOFs.

summaryOfNewsArticle: In northern Pakistan’s mountainous regions, Indigenous knowledge—such as observing natural signs like heavy rainfall or roaring sounds and using traditional signals like gunfire—is being relied upon to predict and respond to glacial lake outburst floods (GLOFs), especially when official early warning systems fail. Despite a $37 million GLOF-II project launched in 2017, many systems remain non-operational due to lack of trust, poor maintenance, and lack of communication with rescue teams. Community members like shepherds Wasiyat Khan and Mohammad Hussain have demonstrated that timely human-based alerts can save lives without casualties, even during major floods. This highlights a critical gap: while technology is being deployed, it lacks community trust and real-time integration. Pakistan, ranked among the top 10 climate-vulnerable nations, faces increasing glacial melt and flooding due to rising temperatures—1.3°C since 1950s—making Indigenous knowledge a vital, resilient alternative to underperforming technological systems.
title: How Indigenous knowledge is aiding Pakistan’s fight against climate change
